ticket.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
ticket.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend
ticket.original-body:
Add yajl-ruby as one of the JSON parser backends in Rails 3 (and 2.3 once it's back-ported).
This would be especially useful in Rails 3 now that the XML and JSON backends support parsing from an IO as well. The ParamsParser middleware was also updated to take advantage of this (as of this commit): http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/53dda29f8b34073a4b135ee224c1d09c1f10de02
The yajl-ruby JSON backend would be the first plugable parsing backend to support parsing directly from the IO as a stream. Given todays massively-ajax based web applications, and the popularity of JSON as a transport protocol - I think this patch would be welcomed by the community with open arms.
Rick, the attached diff is mostly from your previous patch to add this in your fork. With small modifications to take advantage of the new IO parsing support for the backends.
ticket.latest-body:
Add yajl-ruby as one of the JSON parser backends in Rails 3 (and 2.3 once it's back-ported).
This would be especially useful in Rails 3 now that the XML and JSON backends support parsing from an IO as well. The ParamsParser middleware was also updated to take advantage of this (as of this commit): http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/53dda29f8b34073a4b135ee224c1d09c1f10de02
The yajl-ruby JSON backend would be the first plugable parsing backend to support parsing directly from the IO as a stream. Given todays massively-ajax based web applications, and the popularity of JSON as a transport protocol - I think this patch would be welcomed by the community with open arms.
Rick, the attached diff is mostly from your previous patch to add this in your fork. With small modifications to take advantage of the new IO parsing support for the backends.
ticket.original-body-html:
Add yajl-ruby as one of the JSON parser backends in Rails 3 (and 2.3 once it's back-ported).

This would be especially useful in Rails 3 now that the XML and JSON backends support parsing from an IO as well. The ParamsParser middleware was also updated to take advantage of this (as of this commit): http://github.com/rails/rails/co...

The yajl-ruby JSON backend would be the first plugable parsing backend to support parsing directly from the IO as a stream. Given todays massively-ajax based web applications, and the popularity of JSON as a transport protocol - I think this patch would be welcomed by the community with open arms.

Rick, the attached diff is mostly from your previous patch to add this in your fork. With small modifications to take advantage of the new IO parsing support for the backends.

version.body:
Add yajl-ruby as one of the JSON parser backends in Rails 3 (and 2.3 once it's back-ported).
This would be especially useful in Rails 3 now that the XML and JSON backends support parsing from an IO as well. The ParamsParser middleware was also updated to take advantage of this (as of this commit): http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/53dda29f8b34073a4b135ee224c1d09c1f10de02
The yajl-ruby JSON backend would be the first plugable parsing backend to support parsing directly from the IO as a stream. Given todays massively-ajax based web applications, and the popularity of JSON as a transport protocol - I think this patch would be welcomed by the community with open arms.
Rick, the attached diff is mostly from your previous patch to add this in your fork. With small modifications to take advantage of the new IO parsing support for the backends.
version.body-html:
Add yajl-ruby as one of the JSON parser backends in Rails 3 (and 2.3 once it's back-ported).

This would be especially useful in Rails 3 now that the XML and JSON backends support parsing from an IO as well. The ParamsParser middleware was also updated to take advantage of this (as of this commit): http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/53dda29f8b34073a4b135ee224c1d0...

The yajl-ruby JSON backend would be the first plugable parsing backend to support parsing directly from the IO as a stream. Given todays massively-ajax based web applications, and the popularity of JSON as a transport protocol - I think this patch would be welcomed by the community with open arms.

Rick, the attached diff is mostly from your previous patch to add this in your fork. With small modifications to take advantage of the new IO parsing support for the backends.
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body: Doh, I wrote a [Rails 3 plugin](http://github.com/technoweenie/yajl-rails) before I saw this. I'd like to get some people using this before we push this to rails core.
version.body-html: Doh, I wrote a Rails 3 plugin before I saw this. I'd like to get some people using this before we push this to rails core.
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body:
hey!
I keep getting a strange error rendering json in edge rails.
The problem is whith this
@@@ ruby respond_to do |format| format.json { render :json => @devices.to_json(:only => [:id, :name, :unique_identifier], :include => { :device_variables => { :only => [:id, :upper_threshold, :lower_threshold], :methods => [:current_value, :name, :unit] } } ) } format.xml { render :xml => { :error => "not found" }, :status => 404 } format.html { render :file => "public/404.html", :status => 404 } end @@@
returns a strange error: wrong argument type Hash (expected Data)
But not if I do a simpler
@@@ ruby @devices.to_json() @@@
I have the yajl rails plugin installed, any ideas?
Can I help?
Here is the full stack trace:
TypeError in DevicesController#index
wrong argument type Hash (expected Data)
RAILS_ROOT: /Users/paki/Work/freshout/ugmo-v2 Application Trace | Framework Trace | Full Trace

version.body-html:
hey!

I keep getting a strange error rendering json in edge rails.

The problem is whith this

respond_to do |format|
        format.json   { 
          render :json             => @devices.to_json(:only => [:id, :name, :unique_identifier], 
            :include               => { 
              :device_variables    => { 
                :only              => [:id, :upper_threshold, :lower_threshold],
                :methods           => [:current_value, :name, :unit]
              } 
            }
          )
        }
        format.xml  { render :xml  => { :error => "not found" }, :status => 404 }
        format.html { render :file => "public/404.html", :status => 404 }
      end

returns a strange error: wrong argument type Hash (expected Data)

But not if I do a simpler

 @devices.to_json()

I have the yajl rails plugin installed, any ideas?

Can I help?

Here is the full stack trace:

version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body:
1) make sure your edge rails is up to date. 2) Use `ActiveSupport::JSON.encode(@devices, :only....)`.
Every JSON library implements #to_json differently, so you can't rely on it anymore. For more info, check the changelogs, or wait for the release announcement when the Rails 3 changes are blogged.
version.body-html:
1) make sure your edge rails is up to date.
2) Use ActiveSupport::JSON.encode(@devices, :only....).

Every JSON library implements #to_json differently, so you can't rely
on it anymore. For more info, check the changelogs, or wait for the
release announcement when the Rails 3 changes are blogged.
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body:
So the strange thing is, yajl-ruby only overrides to_json if you specifically require 'yajl/json_gem' somewhere. Your yajl-rails plugin doesn't do that, so I'd also assume to_json would work the way Francisco has it above.
That being said, `ActiveSupport::JSON.encode(@devices, :only....)` should work fine.
version.body-html:
So the strange thing is, yajl-ruby only overrides to_json if you specifically require 'yajl/json_gem' somewhere. Your yajl-rails plugin doesn't do that, so I'd also assume to_json would work the way Francisco has it above.

That being said, ActiveSupport::JSON.encode(@devices, :only....) should work fine.
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body: Sure, that may be true. Maybe another json lib is being loaded? This part of rails has changed a lot even between 2.3 and 3.0. There'll be some clear guidance on how to proceed when Rails 3 is released.
version.body-html:
Sure, that may be true. Maybe another json lib is being loaded? This
part of rails has changed a lot even between 2.3 and 3.0. There'll be
some clear guidance on how to proceed when Rails 3 is released.
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body:
What do you guys think about getting this into core? My fork of Rick's plugin should be up to date with both changes to the yajl-ruby API and the Rails JSON backend API. http://github.com/brianmario/yajl-rails
I think it's safe to say enough people are using it (it was also mentioned in the 2.3.3 release notes as being one of the JSON backends) to justify finally getting it into core. Thoughts?
version.body-html:
What do you guys think about getting this into core?
My fork of Rick's plugin should be up to date with both changes to the yajl-ruby API and the Rails JSON backend API.
http://github.com/brianmario/yajl-rails

I think it's safe to say enough people are using it (it was also mentioned in the 2.3.3 release notes as being one of the JSON backends) to justify finally getting it into core. Thoughts?
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body: +1 for core. Much nicer than the jsongem backend.
version.body-html: +1 for core. Much nicer than the jsongem backend.
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body: Here's the patch, hopefully now there's no excuse ;)
version.body-html: Here's the patch, hopefully now there's no excuse ;)
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body: Btw, I'm pretty sure it'll apply cleanly to the 2.3.x and 3.x branches
version.body-html: Btw, I'm pretty sure it'll apply cleanly to the 2.3.x and 3.x branches
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body: Sorry, the author line was wrong in that patch - use this one instead
version.body-html: Sorry, the author line was wrong in that patch - use this one instead
version.tag: backend io json parsing patch stream streaming yajl yajl-ruby
version.title: yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend

version.body:
(from [a96bf4ab5e73fccdafb78b99e8a122cc2172b505]) Add yajl-ruby as a JSON parsing backend
[#2666 state:committed]
Signed-off-by: Jeremy Kemper <jeremy@bitsweat.net> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/a96bf4ab5e73fccdafb78b99e8a122cc2172b505
version.body-html:
